review: The TV commercials give that idea that you can easily transfer (cast) any form of media from your handheld device to your television.  Not exactly!!! There was no way for me to cast my personal photos & videos from my iPad mini. The Chrome website says that software to do that has not been developed for the device yet. I am on satellite internet with limited bandwith (the joys of living in the boondocks), so using Chromecast for streaming media was out of the question. Oh well, I guess I'm back to HDMI cables for now...Setup was fairly simple, although no instructions included in packaging.

review: The Google Chromecast device is worth what you pay for it.For playing TV and shows and movies from Google Play, Netflix, Hulu Plus and other places it was specifically designed for - it does an acceptable job. However occasionally, even though I do have a fast Internet Connection - it will pause for buffering.At this time, I am not sure if the buffering is the device's fault - or due to the fact my tablet doesn't have an overly fast processor.My biggest qualm and the reason I will not rate the device a full five stars is due to the Google Cast application that runs in Google Chrome on your desktop or laptop.Trying to use this app for streaming video from your laptop or desktop is a joke. In using it, no matter what setting you utilize - the Chromecast device will drop it's WiFi connection every few minutes.And needless to say, Google's forum support might as well be non-existent. I submitted this problem to the Google forum several weeks ago and still have not received even a single response.Botttom line: In using the designed apps specifically built for this device (except Google Cast), the Chromecast device does well and it's worth the $$$. But if you are looking for something to stream movies, TV shows, etc from places like Crackle.com via Chrome's Google Cast app - forget it.
author: Amazon Customer
